rsbNotes.title: Mark 16:1
rsbNotes.text:
16:1 Sabbath was past. At sunset (6:00 p.m.) on Saturday evening, a time appropriate for buying spices but not for visiting tombs.

anoint. Anointing was a way of showing affection (14:8 note), as in the West today one sends flowers.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 16:3
rsbNotes.text: 16:3 Who will roll away the stone. They had seen the “very large” (v. 4) stone put in its place (15:46 note).

rsbNotes.title: Mark 16:5
rsbNotes.text:
16:5 entering the tomb. They entered the vestibule of the burial chamber, at the far end of which was the individual niche (a bench or shelf) where Jesus’ body had been laid (15:46 note).

young man. Matt. 28:2 says the women met an angel at the tomb.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 16:6
rsbNotes.text:
16:6 of Nazareth. See note 1:24.

He has risen. If the Gospel of Mark reaches its climax in the confession that Jesus is the Son of God (15:39 note), a second climax is reached with the declaration of His resurrection, which attests that His preaching concerning the coming of the kingdom in power is true. See notes 1:15 and 9:1; “The Resurrection of Jesus” at Luke 24:2.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 16:7
rsbNotes.text:
16:7 and Peter. These two words make all the difference in the enormous role that Peter would play in the subsequent history of redemption. By them Mark indicates, as he brings his Gospel to an end (16:9–20 note), that Jesus’ work of preparation of the Twelve will not be lost.

he is going before. See note 14:28.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 16:8
rsbNotes.text: 16:8 afraid. If vv. 9–20 are not original (see below), then the Gospel of Mark ends with this sentence. This would be a surprising conclusion for a document that purports to be a “gospel,” a proclamation of “good news.” An opposing consideration is that the word translated “afraid” also means “reverential fear,” and the same state of mind is produced in the disciples at the sight of Jesus’ Transfiguration (9:6), a type of the future resurrection. But the women’s initial silence was really disobedience (v. 7).

rsbNotes.title: Mark 16:9–20
rsbNotes.text: 16:9–20 Scholars differ regarding whether these verses were originally part of this Gospel. Some important early Greek manuscripts lack these verses, other manuscripts have vv. 9–20 (known as the “Longer Ending”), and still others have a “Shorter Ending” (roughly one verse long). A few manuscripts have both the “Shorter Ending” and the “Longer Ending.” Because of these differences, some scholars believe that vv. 9–20 were added later and not written by Mark. On the other hand, the verses are cited by writers from the late second century and are found in the overwhelming majority of existing Greek manuscripts of the Gospel of Mark. For other scholars, these facts establish the authenticity of the passage.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 16:9
rsbNotes.text: 16:9 Mary Magdalene. See note 15:40.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 16:12
rsbNotes.text: 16:12 two of them. Compare Luke 24:13–35.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 16:15
rsbNotes.text: 16:15 Go into all the world. Compare Matt. 28:19.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 16:16
rsbNotes.text: 16:16 baptized. See “Infant Baptism” at Gen. 17:11.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 16:17
rsbNotes.text: 16:17 signs. All of the things predicted here (except drinking deadly poison) are recorded in the New Testament, especially in Acts. See also Rom. 15:19; Heb. 2:3, 4. Stories about some of the apostles surviving being forced to drink poison are found in early Christian literature outside the Bible.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 16:19
rsbNotes.text: 16:19 right hand of God. A position symbolizing the authority that Jesus shares with God the Father (14:62; Phil. 2:9; cf. Ps. 110:1).

rsbNotes.title: Mark 16:20
rsbNotes.text: 16:20 confirmed the message by accompanying signs. See note on v. 17.
